title: A renewed and more limited FOIR following a refusal: information about the relationship between the Charities Commission and Sheffield Council

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
A previous FOIR, after a long delay and an Internal Review, has been refused on cost grounds.
I was invited to make a new Request more limited in scope:
Please provide all information (emails,letters, meeting minutes,  phone conversation notes,etc)  relating to communications between the Charities Commission and Sheffield City Council in which there is mention of   Graves Park/Norton Nurseries between 2005 and the present.
Yours faithfully,
Russell Johnson

Dear Russell Johnson,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Charity Commission
correspondence on Graves Park/Norton Nurseries which we received on
24/01/2024.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 21/02/2024. Please do not hesitate to contact
us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Mr Johnson
Thank you for your request for information relating to Charity Commission
correspondence on Graves Park/Norton Nurseries, which we received on
24/01/2024.
We appreciate this is a new request following our refusal of your last,
which exceeded the “appropriate limit” cost of compliance. Unfortunately,
your revision still requires a level of processing far beyond the 18 hour
limit specified in the [1]Freedom of Information and Data Protection
(Appropriate Limit and Fees) Regulations 2004 (SI 2004 No. 3244). We are
therefore declining to process it under section 12 of the Act.
Whilst you have reduced your request from all communications from the
Charity Commission to the council since 2005, to only those relating to
Graves Park/Norton Nurseries, you have increased the scope of the request
to include the council’s communications with the Charity Commission.
Consider the two-way correspondence between two public authorities over 18
years. Changes in format between paper and electronic, changes in email
addresses during that time, changes in council organisation, turnover of
staff, changes in case management systems, records on shared drives,
records in emails. You have specifically mentioned: information (emails,
letters, meeting minutes, phone conversation notes, etc.)
As an experienced user of FOI over many years, we want to ask you, with no
diminution of your rights nor our responsibilities, to empathise with the
effort to locate, retrieve and extract this information from at least
Property Records, Parks and Countryside, Legal Services, and not excluding
Finance & Commercial Services, the Chief Executive’s Office, Policy,
Democratic services, and services not even mentioned.
An insight, if we may, into Legal Services alone: the effort taken, for
this new request of yours, just locating the files and the deed packets to
interrogate has taken two and a half hours. We estimate two hours to go
through each file and this is before looking through eight deed packets,
which should take an hour in total. This takes Legal Service’s time to
20.5 hours. And that is before we go to archived electronic records and
the records of senior lawyers.
These figures would be replicated across the council.
We do want to be able to respond to you. Our objections are only technical
and have no bearing on the content of any material, which may or may not
engage exemptions. We expect though the balance of the public interest to
favour disclosure.
So, what to do? We cannot impute motive but assume that the Rose Garden
café closure must have influenced your request. Would it not be possible
to confine your request to a much shorter period around that event. Of
course, we apologise for any presumption and do not want to tie your hands
in any way.
If you would like to narrow down the focus of your request, we would be
happy to process your revised request as a new request for information
under the Freedom of Information Act 2000.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
